facts.text: Two cross appeals arise out of two orders and judgments of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Nagpur

anchor.surface_text: These are two cross appeals which arise out of two orders and judgments of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Nagpur.

facts.text: Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 139 of 1956 is the assessee

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in Civil Appeal No. 139 of 1956 is the assessee and that in Civil Appeal No. 207 of 1959 is the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 207 of 1959 is the Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in Civil Appeal No. 139 of 1956 is the assessee and that in Civil Appeal No. 207 of 1959 is the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 139 of 1956 relates to assessment years 1944-45, 1945-46, 1946-47 and 1947-48

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 139 of 1956 relates to assessment years 1944-45, 1945-46, 1946-47 and 1947-48 and Civil Appeal No. 207 of 1959 relates to the assessment years 1948-49 and 1949-50.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 207 of 1959 relates to assessment years 1948-49 and 1949-50

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 139 of 1956 relates to assessment years 1944-45, 1945-46, 1946-47 and 1947-48 and Civil Appeal No. 207 of 1959 relates to the assessment years 1948-49 and 1949-50.

facts.text: Accounting years in both appeals were Samvat years

anchor.surface_text: The accounting years in both the appeals were Samvat years.

facts.text: Appellant in C.A. No. 139 of 1956 was karta of Hindu undivided family consisting of appellant, his wife and three sons

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant in C. A. No. 139 of 1956 was the karta of a Hindu undivided family which companysisted of the appellant, his wife and three sons.

facts.text: Family owned various movable and immovable properties and business and was assessed as Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: The family owned endorsed various movable and immoveable properties and business and were being assessed as a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: There was a partition on October 16, 1944

anchor.surface_text: There was a partition on October 16, 1944, and the deed of partition was executed on December 30, 1944, and was register on January 2, 1945.

facts.text: Deed of partition executed on December 30, 1944

anchor.surface_text: There was a partition on October 16, 1944, and the deed of partition was executed on December 30, 1944, and was register on January 2, 1945.

facts.text: Deed of partition registered on January 2, 1945

anchor.surface_text: There was a partition on October 16, 1944, and the deed of partition was executed on December 30, 1944, and was register on January 2, 1945.

facts.text: Appellant claimed partition given full effect and applied under section 25A(3) and 25A of Income-tax Act for exemption

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that the portion was given full effect to and, therefore, the members of the disrupted family applied under section 25A and section 25  4  of the Income-tax Act claiming exemption and reduction of tax liability for the various years of assessment and also prayed for an order under section 25A.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected application holding no partition and deed not meant to be acted upon

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officer rejected the application holding that there was numberpartition as alleged by the appellant and that the deed of partition was number meant to be acted upon.

facts.text: Appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then went in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner which was dismissed and so was the appeal to the Tribunal.

facts.text: High Court directed Tribunal to state case on question whether legal evidence for Tribunal's inference that partition not genuine

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, he applied to the High Court under section 66  2  of the Income-tax Act and the High Court directed the Tribunal to stated the case on the following question. Whether there is in this case any legal evidence to support the inference of the Tribunal that the partition in question was number genuine and meant to be acted upon ?

facts.text: Partition in question dated October 16, 1944

anchor.surface_text: The partition in question which was set up was one dated October 16, 1944.

facts.text: High Court decided reference against appellant

anchor.surface_text: The case was stated but the reference was decided against the appellant.

facts.text: On May 6, 1950, respondents Mathuradas filed civil suit to declare partition deed dated December 30, 1944 null and void

anchor.surface_text: On May 6, 1950, the respondents, Mathuradas, filed a civil suits praying that the partition as evidenced by the deed dated December 30, 1944, be declared null and void and a fresh partition be made between the parties.

facts.text: Court held partition deed genuine, fair, binding; joint family ceased as from December 30, 1944

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt held the partition evidenced by the deed of partition to be genuine, fair and binding on all the parties and that the joint family had ceased to exist as from December 30, 1944.

facts.text: Tribunal decided in favour of Mathuradas except house at Bikaner

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Appellant Tribunal, it was decided in favour of Mathuradas, respondents, excepting in regard to a house at Bikaner.

facts.text: High Court answered reference in favour of respondent that there was legal evidence for finding partition genuine

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ordered a reference to be made but answered the question referred in favour of the respondent and against the Commissioner.

facts.text: Additional facts including oath statements of sons proved before Tribunal supporting genuineness of partition dated December 30, 1944

anchor.surface_text: Considering the additional facts which were placed before the Tribunal and on which it had given a finding in favour of the respondent, Mathuradas, the High Court held that there was material in favour of the partition set up. ... statements on oath of the sons of the respondent and the other relevant material it cannot be said that there were numbermaterials for the Appellant Tribunal for finding in favour of the respondent and in favour of the partition being genuine.

facts.text: Partition set up in second case was December 30, 1944, different from October 16, 1944 in first case

anchor.surface_text: But the partition set up in this case was of December 30, 1944, whereas the partition set up in the earlier case was of October 16, 1944.
